image.altText: A bushfire is seen in the background behind a sandbar on a quiet beach

props.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with hundreds of firefighters battling blazes in Victoria while an emergency warning for Flinders Island in Tasmania's north-east has been downgraded. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in Victoria reach emergency level as Tasmanian fire downgraded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Phil Graham lives in Stockdale, northeast of Briagolong, and has been fighting the east Victoria fire since 1am AEDT. He says fireys have been able to save a section of pine plantations. "[It's] pretty much just young pine, which we have lost most of. "But we're pretty luck we've been able to keep it out of the mature pine forest which is a fairly big asset for the plantation people so we're pretty happy about that. "That's a big win for us."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'That's a big win for us': Gippsland fireys save valuable pine forest

children.content: lives in Stockdale, northeast of Briagolong, and has been fighting the east Victoria fire since 1am AEDT.
He says fireys have been able to save
"[It's] pretty much just young pine, which we have lost most of.
"But we're pretty luck we've been able to keep it out of the mature pine forest which is a fairly big asset for the plantation people so we're pretty happy about that.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Watch and Act warnings have been issued for Coolagolite, Kearsley and Martinsville where firefighters are responding to bushfires. In Coolagolite, the fire is burning near Coolagolite Road, 12 kilometres west of Bermagui. It's moving in an easterly direction under strong westerly winds. Nearby properties are told to prepare now. In Kearsley, the fire is burning in an easterly direction, 5 kilometres south-east of Cessnock and is out of control. In Martinsville, the fire is burning in Watagan National Park, 11 kilometres north-west of Morriset. It's moving in a south-easterly direction towards Mount Nellinda Road. Nearby residents are told to prepare now. Watch and Act is a heightened level of threat. It means conditions are changing and you need to start taking action now to protect you and your family.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New fire warnings issued for NSW communities

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good news for the residents of Flinders Island, north-east of Tasmania. The bushfire warning at West End Road, Boat Habour Road and near communities of Pine Scrub and Leeka has been downgraded to Advice level. This means there is currently no immediate threat .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Warning for Flinders Island fire downgraded

children.content: Good news for the residents of Flinders Island, north-east of Tasmania.

image.altText: A boat moored by a small jetty with an orange fire burning in the background over the water.

props.synopsis: Spot fires are flaring up 11 kilometres ahead of an East Gippsland fire front that has residents in an isolated coastal town preparing to evacuate by boat.

title.children: Victorian residents prepare for boat evacuations after Gippsland town cut off by bushfires

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair cries while sitting in a police interview room

props.synopsis: Biannca Edmunds has been sentenced to 26 years' jail after a botched assassination plan she hatched with her husband, targeting her ex-partner, resulted in both mens' deaths.

title.children: Judge says woman showed 'extreme' entitlement by plotting to kill her ex-partner over custody issues

image.altText: A man in a burnt out forest

props.synopsis: Despite living in some of the most bushfire-prone parts of the country, these far east Gippsland residents can't contemplate moving anywhere else, even as they watch a fire emergency unfold elsewhere in the region.

title.children: Be prepared or 'bugger off', says Black Summer survivor gearing up for early fire season as region battles emergency

image.altText: bush fire from above

props.synopsis: Firefighters are still working to control a blaze that swept across an area containing unexploded WWII bombs in northern New South Wales.

title.children: Firefighters stand down as fire sweeps over RAAF air weapons range

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

props.synopsis: The federal Labor minister was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease during her first pregnancy and says, like others with invisible diseases, she does not want people drawing their own conclusions about her illness.

title.children: Why Anika Wells doesn't publicly name her chronic illness

image.altText: A drone shot of a new housing estate, with houses stretching as far as the eye can see

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank is widely tipped to keep interest rates on hold when it meets today, but more hikes are expected later this year as 550,000 people come off fixed mortgages. The RBA itself warns that could put more people in financial stress, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: RBA warns 'solid middle-to-upper-income' people are the new borrowers in financial stress

image.altText: a map of eastern australia showing hot temperatures for those parts

props.synopsis: The frequent spells of early spring heat resulted in Australia's third-warmest September on record since 1910, with a national temperature 2.4C above the climatological average.

title.children: The heat won't stay: Temperatures to drop by as much as 20 degrees in 48 hours

image.altText: Illustration of Australia with night sky and stars in background and yellow circle in middle of Australia.

props.synopsis: On October 14, every Australian will be asked to answer a yes or no question. What you write on the ballot paper will determine whether our constitution is changed for the first time in more than four decades. Here's everything you need to know before you vote.

title.children: Your Voice voting cheat sheet: All your referendum questions, answered

image.altText: A young woman in a fluoro vest with pink glasses standing between trains.

props.synopsis: Chelsea Taylor thought university was the only option after school. But after three unfinished degrees and $30,000 in student debt, she felt "really, really lost" — until she became a train driver.

title.children: After racking up a big student debt, Chelsea became a train driver. She says career advice is limiting teenagers

image.altText: Three people stand in the background, between two purple and white YES signs

props.synopsis: The Yes23 campaign has been asked to keep signs for the Yes vote coloured in purple and white away from Australian Electoral Commission signage.

title.children: Yes23 campaign warned over signs which could 'mislead' voters at polling stations

image.altText: Stan Grant in a suit and short

props.synopsis: Michael Steven Davis, 41, allegedly used his Facebook and Twitter profiles to threaten "serious harm" in May.

title.children: Man accused of abusing Stan Grant online has three charges dropped, offers to apologise

image.altText: Two people sit on a stage smiling, both wearing t-shirts that say Vote No to the Voice of Division

props.synopsis: More than 1,000 vocal No supporters are urged by Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Nyunggai Warren Mundine not to get complacent ahead of the historic referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Price and Mundine issue rallying cry to No crowd in Perth as Voice vote draws closer

image.altText: Composite image of two photos of a man - a selfie with him smoking a cigar and a mugshot. Around him are passport stamps.

props.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: This Australian is sitting in a foreign prison cell. He's ready to come clean about his life undercover

image.altText: Smoke fills the air over mountainous bushland.

props.synopsis: A weather front is bringing rain relief for emergency services tackling a bushfire on Flinders Island that earlier forced evacuations — with residents urged to continue monitoring the "changeable" conditions.

title.children: Rain relief for crews fighting Flinders Island bushfire

image.altText: A man stands with two woman, wearing white t-shirts with a baby's name and photo on the front.

props.synopsis: Jake Robert Luscombe will be eligible for parole in October 2026 after shaking a baby girl to death.

title.children: Man sentenced to five years in prison for shaking death of seven-month-old

image.altText: Anthony Daniels smiles holding up a gold light-up robotic looking head.

props.synopsis: A trove of costumes and props will go under the hammer in a sale of film and television memorabilia worth around $23 million.

title.children: C-3PO's head, Titanic costumes among memorabilia for sale at film auction

image.altText: A girl sits up in bed, hugging her knees to her chest. Her face is blurred by a sheet of tempered glass.

props.synopsis: ABC Investigations has established more than 1,500 people have reported alleged sexual assaults and harassment in mental health wards over the past six years in Australia. It is launching a national crowdsourced investigation into mental health units and is asking people to share their experiences.

title.children: Florence was allegedly raped in her hospital room. She wants her story told to keep others safe

image.altText: An illustration shows several hands, arranged in a circle, holding sheets of paper marked with the Chinese flag.

props.synopsis: Australian law firms acting for the Chinese state are simultaneously completing work for the Australian government, raising concerns over sensitive work being done by those firms.

title.children: Beijing-owned businesses using Australian law firms to advise on takeovers of critical projects

image.altText: A woman smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: The survivor of a terrifying shark attack at Beachport in South Australia's south-east initially thought the animal was another swimmer, her husband says — but he has little doubt his wife will return to the water after recovering in hospital and at home.

title.children: Shark that attacked early morning swimmer 'looked like a white pointer', husband says

image.altText: A teen on the left high fives a senior on the right. Both are wearing bright yellow sweat headbands and black shirts

props.synopsis: With almost one in three Australians reporting feeling lonely, an intergenerational friendship could be the antidote. If you're looking to connect with new friends outside your social bubble, but you're not sure where to start, read on.

title.children: Inspired by Old People's Home for Teenagers? Tap into these ideas to build intergenerational connections

image.altText: Hands holding glasses give cheers, as confetti falls.

props.synopsis: As the government introduces draft legislation to tighten concessions for the largest superannuation account holders, new data reveals 11 more Australians have joined the ranks of account holders with more than $100 million in super.

title.children: Tax office reveals 11 more Australians reporting super balances of more than $100 million

image.altText: Four white men in suits stand side by side.

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: US late-night hosts return after five-month absence and NT police pick up large volume of surgical scissors using metal-detecting wands. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Split screen image of a woman and a man on ABC's Q+A.

props.synopsis: As Senator Malarndirri McCarthy reveals the moment she felt most "disempowered", a debate focused on who the Voice will help takes over Q+A.

title.children: 'Disadvantage' locked into the constitution or 'significant moment'? Voice debate heats up on Q+A

image.altText: Kacey and Layne stand together smiling on a suburban street.

props.synopsis: Less than half of the federal government's promised urgent care clinics have opened, months after the policy was supposed to be delivered.

title.children: 'He was hysterical': It took hours for Kacey's son to receive treatment for a broken elbow

image.altText: A line of utes entering a gate.

props.synopsis: On Monday evening an 18-year-old man handed himself in to Wagga Wagga police station where he was charged with three offences, including assault occasioning actual bodily harm.

title.children: Teenager charged after man allegedly set on fire at Deniliquin Ute Muster over the long weekend

image.altText: Trees in silhouette in front of a lightning strike.

props.synopsis: Tens of thousands of homes and businesses have been left without power across South Australia following a night of wild weather that included intense lightning and very strong wind gusts.

title.children: Emergency volunteer suffers electric shock as 'lightning show' cuts power to thousands of SA properties

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

props.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear

image.altText: Thanasi Kokkinakis crouches down and leans his head on his racquet

props.synopsis: The Australian Open will start on a Sunday in 2024, becoming a 15-day event in a bid to reduce the pressure on players and fans from late-night finishes.

title.children: Australian Open set for shake-up to eliminate 'ridiculously late' finishes

image.altText: Taylor Adams in tears hugs Darcy Moore

props.synopsis: AFL premiership coach Craig McRae says all Collingwood players who featured during the season deserve medals after the club's grand final triumph.

title.children: 'It just seems wrong': More Magpies deserving of AFL Premiership medals says Cox, McRae

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Gorgon gas project on the coast of Western Australia.

props.synopsis: Australia may be a quarry to the world, and the mining of its natural resources might underpin our national budget. But we can and must demand better corporate ethics than this, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A 'sham' workforce in WA has exposed the shadowy ways of global oil and gas — and workers are paying the price

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

props.synopsis: The local share market falls sharply as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the value of the Australian dollar, gold and oil suffer heavy losses. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX wipes out all its gains of 2023, Australian dollar sinks to 11-month low ahead of Reserve Bank decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: You can tell things are getting a little gloomy when the share market falls back to where it was when the year began. The ASX 200 has now fallen 0.8% since January 1 (as you can see in this chart below). Looking at it another way, the last time it fell to this level (6,942 points) was March 20, so the benchmark index is technically at a six-month low.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian share market erases all of this year's gains

children.content: You can tell things are getting a little gloomy when the share market falls back to where it was when the year began.
has now fallen 0.8% since January 1 (as you can see in this chart below).
Looking at it another way, the last time it fell to this level (6,942 points) was
, so the benchmark index is technically at a six-month low.

props.alt: A line graph showing the ASX 200 is back to where it was when the year began, after recent heavy falls.

children.content: The ASX 200 has wiped out all its gains for 2023.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has recovered some of its earlier losses, but it's still very much in negative territory. The ASX 200 was down 1.4% to 6,936 points, by 12:25pm AEDT. Healthcare is the only sector trading higher, led by gains from Resmed (+1.2%) and CSL (+1%). Mining and energy stocks are still the worst performers, including Perseus Mining (-4.8%), Beach Energy (-4.8%) and Evolution Mining (-4.4%), after a big drop in gold and oil prices overnight. The Australian dollar is trading at 63.55 US cents (having lost more than 1% overnight), and remains near an 11-month low.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets at midday: ASX 200 falls 1.4 per cent

children.content: The local share market has recovered some of its earlier losses, but it's still very much in negative territory.
Healthcare is the only sector trading higher, led by gains from
Mining and energy stocks are still the worst performers, including
(-4.4%), after a big drop in gold and oil prices overnight.
The Australian dollar is trading at 63.55 US cents (having lost more than 1% overnight), and remains near an 11-month low.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Share market across the world have performed quite badly in the past three months. Several major indexes posted their biggest quarterly (and monthly) losses all year: So what's causing investors to get spooked? One factor is the comments that central bank officials, worldwide have made about the interest rate outlook. Earlier today, Federal Reserve vice-chair for supervision Michael Barr said he feels US rates are "at or near" a level that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to the Fed's 2% target. It is also likely, he told the Forecasters Club of New York, that rates will need to stay high for some time to bring inflation down to target, and he is confident the Fed will get that job done. Senior officials from the US, European, British and Australian central banks have recently made similar statements (reiterating that the next move on rates is "data dependent"), which aren't exactly groundbreaking. Investors are now beginning to take them more seriously, and are re-thinking their earlier expectations about rate cuts happening soon. Bond sell-off, stronger US greenback, weaker share markets So the "higher for longer" narrative has caused a sell-off in the government bond (or debt) market, which has pushed the US 10-year Treasury yield to its highest level in 16 years (around the time of the Global Financial Crisis). As the price of bonds fall, their yields go up (the price and yield move in opposite directions). It means the US government would need to pay higher interest, to entice more people to lend it money (by purchasing its Treasurey bonds). And that boosted the US dollar to its highest level since November last year (and weakened other currencies, like the Australian dollar, in the process). As more investors invest in the 'safe' greenback, they're pulling their money out of riskier assets (like the share market), which is why the ASX 200, S & P 500, Stoxx 600, Nikkei and other indexes suffered their worst quarters of the year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why are stock markets doing so poorly ... while the US dollar is surging

children.content: Share market across the world have performed quite badly in the past three months.
Several major indexes posted their biggest quarterly (and monthly) losses all year:
So what's causing investors to get spooked?
One factor is the comments that central bank officials, worldwide have made about the interest rate outlook.
Earlier today, Federal Reserve vice-chair for supervision Michael Barr said he feels US rates are "at or near" a level that is sufficiently restrictive to bring inflation down to the Fed's 2% target.
It is also likely, he told the Forecasters Club of New York, that rates will need to
to bring inflation down to target, and he is confident the Fed will get that job done.

Senior officials from the US, European, British and Australian central banks have recently made similar statements (reiterating that the next move on rates is "data dependent"), which aren't exactly groundbreaking.
Investors are now beginning to take them more seriously, and are re-thinking their earlier expectations about rate cuts happening soon.
Bond sell-off, stronger US greenback, weaker share markets

So the "higher for longer" narrative has caused a sell-off in the government bond (or debt) market, which has pushed the US 10-year Treasury yield to its highest level in 16 years (around the time of the Global Financial Crisis).
As the price of bonds fall, their yields go up (the price and yield move in opposite directions).

props.alt: A line graph showing the cost of borrowing money for the US government has surged to a 16-year high.

children.content: The US 10-year Treasury yield surged to its highest level since late 2007.
It means the US government would need to pay higher interest, to entice more people to lend it money (by purchasing its Treasurey bonds).
And that boosted the US dollar to its highest level since November last year (and weakened other currencies, like the Australian dollar, in the process).
As more investors invest in the 'safe' greenback, they're pulling their money out of riskier assets (like the share market), which is why the ASX 200, S
P 500, Stoxx 600, Nikkei and other indexes suffered their worst quarters of the year.

image.altText: A pilot stands beside heavily-armed rebels in Papua.

props.synopsis: Rebels were armed with military-grade weapons and arrows when a battle broke out between them and a joint military and police force, with the group saying the deaths of their fighters would not lead to their surrender.

title.children: Members of Papuan rebel group behind kidnapping of New Zealand pilot killed in clashes with security forces

image.altText: Houses under construction in the background with building materials in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A group of councils in the Loddon Mallee region is working to jointly appoint a dedicated regional housing officer, as part of a region-wide housing action plan.

title.children: Councils band together to tackle housing crisis crippling regional Victoria
